captions.text:
(SINGING) When you want to
make a circle, how is it done?

Well, you probably will
start with the radius 1.

Then use a compass or a string,
and use a paper or the ground.

And if the radius is 1,
how far did you go around?

If you pick a certain distance,
and you pick a certain spot,

and you put the two together,
then what have you got?

It makes a very special shape,
and now you are the inventor,

if you take all of the
points a certain distance
from your center.

And you've got a
great collection,
and it is a great invention.

And it makes a lovely circle,
well, depending on dimension.

Because it's 1, 2, 3, then
there's 4 and even more.

But for a circle,
how much circle's

there if you take the
distance and compare?

I know what you are thinking,
what about that other guy?

The one that's
sometimes pronounced

pee, and it's sometimes
pronounced pi?

I mean, it's fine if you
are building, but does not
belong in math.

All the equations make
more sense when you use taw
or you use taff.

Well, you get the same
answers no matter which way.

We get further from truth
when we obscure what we say.

You know that math makes sense
when it's beautiful and pure.

So please don't make it
ugly with your bad notation
and awful curriculum.
Use tau, 6.28.

title: A Song About A Circle Constant

comments.text:
I have never learned about tau in my math classes before. After reading a 
lot of the comments below, I'm guessing there is a lot of debate in the 
mathematical community on what is better to use when discussing circles. 
What is the function of tau? It can't be the same as pi; I don't understand 
how that would be possible. This video was very visually appealing to watch 
as well as informative. I think that I am going to go look up the debate on 
tau and pi now! When I put tau into google, the first articles that come up 
are all about the comparison between pi and tau. It is crazy to me that I 
have just been taught to accept pi! This isn't right! One should always 
question what he/she learn. All of this obviously means that this video 
helped me question math. Great job! ﻿

comments.author: barlart

comments.text:
If you want to calculate circumference, it's pi*2*radius. If you want to 
calculate area it's pi*radius*radius.
If you use tau, circumference is tau*radius and area is 
(tau/2)*radius*radius.
So both methods have drawbacks, in that there is an extra 2 in there or an 
extra 1/2. However when using pi, circumference can be written as 
pi*diameter which removes that pesky 2, making pi simpler and therefore 
better.
Also the song "2πr circle, 2πr, area's 2πr." (To the tune of Kumbaya). No 
more reasons needed.﻿

comments.author: JNCressey

comments.text:
+DiEvAlDiEvAl E=mc^2 is not an integrated formula.
1/2mv^2 = int(mv)dv Because *KE = int(momentum)d.velocity*[For some reason 
involving work and F=d(mv)/dt] and momentum = mv
1/2kx^2 = int(kx)dx Because *EPE = int(force)d.extension* and force = kx
1/2at^2  = int(at)dt [or ut+1/2at^2 = int(u+at)dt] Because *displacement = 
int(velocity)d.time* and velocity= u+at

similarily:
*area = int(circumference)d.radius* and circumference = τr
so area = int(τr)dr = 1/2τr^2

What do you notice about all the squared quantities? Velocity, extension, 
time, radius. They're all VARIABLES.
the speed of light c is a constant.
comments.author: JNCressey

comments.text:
Ahh but E=mc^2 is not the complete formula. The complete formula is 
E^2=(mc^2)^2+(pc)^2
comments.author: JayIsADino

comments.text:
+JayIsADino Well, to be perfectly honest you also need to mention E=mc^2. 
You see, there is no 1/2 there, just like in A=πr^2. But on the other hand 
both formulas are based on flawed concepts (so-called relativistic mass, 
and the badly-named so-called real number called π) ;-)

And seriously guys, get a greek leopard layout! All those "tau" and "pi" 
look so ugly...
comments.author: DiEvAlDiEvAl

comments.text:
the point isn't simplifying the equations. it's simplifying the definition. 
it makes much more sense for one full revolution about a circle to be tau 
radians, rather than 2pi radians. so a quarter turn is a quarter tau. one 
sixteenth? one sixteenth tau. the benefit isn't in high level maths, but in 
the core ideas that things like radians are based on.
comments.author: Ben F

comments.text:
see, in archetecture, you are building your ARCH on the diameter, or flat 
surface. a semi circle, essentially. but in math, the circle is the 
simplest "squared" unit. which should actually be conceptualized as 
"circled", when you think about it.

tau^3 = tau *sphered* = phi/golden spiral

(at least that seems correct)
comments.author: Lori Wilson

1/2mv^2
1/2kx^2

Then 1/2Tr^2
It fits!!!

Please go to the tau day page and I can guarantee that you will come out a

about a diameter?*." Tell me that isn't an opinion.

Also, say that you mean a circle is defined by it's radius. Okay, then what 
about the area? You mean you are going to (T/2)r^2? By this pi already 
beats tau in one way.

In my opinion, yes. I *still* think pi and tau are equals. They are both 
NUMBERS, Not those nonsense like "because 2, in any way, is more convenient 
that always getting 1*2, we are changing to using 2 as the basic unit and 
dropping 1."
comments.author: Logo

comments.text: they just think it is an easier way of doing it. Which it is, in opinion.
